questions.text: A 40 year old female with burns over her abdomen, both limbs and back and presented after 8 hours. Which of the following is the formula for calculation of fluid infusion?

choices.text: 2 ml/kg X %TBSA for the next 16 hours
5 ml/kg X %TSBA for the next 16 hours
4 ml/kg X %TSBA for first 8 hours then 2 ml/kg X %TBSA for next 16 hours
4 ml/kg X%TSBA for the next 16 hours

questions.solution:
Fluid resuscitation in burns:

According to ATLS 10th edition, 2018, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA.

First 8 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)
Next 16 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)

For a patient presenting 8 hours after sustaining thermal burns, the total volume using resuscitation formula should be given in the next 16 hours i.e; 2 mL/kg × % TBSA in the next 16 hours while maintaining target urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults.

In adults, urine output should be maintained between 30 and 50 cc/hr to minimize potential over-resuscitation.

 

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

Total percentage of the burnt area is calculated clinically using the rule of nines.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was brought to the casualty ward with a history of road traffic accident (RTA) and head trauma.  Her eye opens to pain, moans, can localize limb towards the pain stimulus on the left hand and away from the pain stimulus on the right hand and both the legs in extended posture. Calculate her GCS.
questions.solution:
The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of this patient is E2V2M5, which comes to a total score of 9.
E2-Eye opens to pain
V2-Moans
M5-Localizes to pain on the left hand (the score represents the best performance elicited, which would be localizing towards the pain stimulus)

Revised Glasgow coma scale for head injury:

Minimum GCS is 3, maximum GCS is 15.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient who was on ventilator and being ventilated for past few days suddenly pulls out of the endotracheal tube. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and reintubate if needed

questions.solution: About half of self-extubated patients may not require re-intubation. Pre-extubation FiO2, PaO2/FiO2, and ventilator mode, as well as gender, may be useful in determining the likelihood that a self-extubated patient will require re-intubation and also watch for spontaneous breathing.

questions.text: The time required for preoxygenation before tracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Preoxygenation with tidal volume breathing of 3 mins is required before tracheal intubation.

Preoxygenation or denitrogenation is the process of replacing nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen.

This delays the onset of critical hypoxia during the period of apnea by 5-8 minutes.

This lengthened apnea time provides an improved margin of safety while the anesthesiologist secures the airway and resumes ventilation.

This was a new question asked in AIIMS Nov-17 and hence a potential repeat in the upcoming sessions. The confusion might arise as there are two methods of preoxygenation. But 3 minutes is the most appropriate answer as explained.

questions.text: Nerve fibre least susceptible to local anesthetic is:
questions.solution:
The nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is type C. The order of susceptibility of nerve fibres to local anaesthetics is B >A-δ > A-γ > A-β > A-α > C i.e

  • B fibres are the most susceptible/least resistant     
  • C fibres are the least susceptible/most resistant

Factors that increase the sensitivity of nerve fibres are :

  • Smaller diameter
  • Unmyelinated nerves
  • Anatomical and physiological factors

*Note: Although theoretically, C fibres are supposed to be the most susceptible to local anaesthetics, practically it was found to be the least susceptible.

Controversial: There is a difference in the opinion quoted by various standard textbooks and authors.

Majority of the sources quote the order of susceptibility of nerve fibres as B >A-δ > A-γ > A-β > A-α > C  

  • Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 6th Edition, Ganong’s review of medical physiology 26th Edition and UpToDate: B >A-δ > A-γ > A-β > A-α > C; where C is the most resistant and B is the least resistant
  • Katzung pharmacology 14th edition:  B > C > A-δ > A-γ > A-β > A-α  where A-α is least susceptible; B is most susceptible
  • Miller’s anaesthesia 9th Edition: B > Aγ > Aδ > Aα=Aβ > C where C is least susceptible; B is the most susceptible
  • Ganong's Physiology 26th Ed. page no. 92, nerve fiber susceptibility to local anesthetics is in the order C > B > A

Hence, the correct answer would solely depend on the reference book used by the examiner while framing the question.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used as an intravenous induction agent?
questions.solution:
Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine that can be used for induction of anesthesia at a dose of 0.1mg/kg, although midazolam is preferred among benzodiazepines.

Benzodiazepines are mainly used for sedation and less commonly for induction of anesthesia due to the availability of better induction agents (propofol, etomidate, ketamine, and thiopentone).

Dexmedetomidine is a selective alpha-2 agonist and is used primarily as an adjuvant. So, a better option would be lorazepam.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence?

choices.text: Assess the patient’s response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR
Check carotid pulse, Start CPR, Call for help and activate ERS, Defibrillate
Defibrillate, Assess response, Check carotid pulse, Maintain airway
Start CPR, Activate ERS, Defibrillate, Check pulse

questions.solution:
BLS sequence:

First step – Assess safety of the surroundings.

Second step - Assess for responsiveness

Third step – Proceed if the patient is unresponsive. Shout for help.

If the patient is unresponsive assess for breathing and carotid pulse simultaneously for no more than 10 seconds.
